prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: In all cases, a restrictive covenant is required to be reasonable with respect to the interests of both parties and also with reference to the public interest.[1] The classic statement is found in Nordenfelt:

… restraints of trade and interference with individual liberty of action may be justified by the special circumstances of a particular case. It is sufficient justification, and indeed it is the only justification, if the restriction is reasonable—reasonable, that is, in reference to the interests of the parties concerned and reasonable in reference to the interests of the public, so framed and so guarded as to afford adequate protection to the party in whose favour it is imposed, while at the same time it is in no way injurious to the public.[2]

Subsequent cases clarified Nordenfelt and further developed the basic legal principles established by that case. The leading English decision of Herbert Morris Ltd. v. Saxelby[3] acknowledged the necessity of balancing the public policy issues involved:

“Public policy requires that every man shall be at liberty to work for himself, and shall not be at liberty to deprive himself or the State of his labour, skill, or talent, by any contract that he enters into. On the other hand, public policy requires that when a man has by skill or by any other means obtained something which he wants to sell, he should be at liberty to sell it in the most advantageous way in the market; and in order to enable him to sell it advantageously in the market it is necessary that he should be able to preclude himself into entering into competition with the purchaser. In such a case the same public policy that enables him to do that does not restrain him from alienating that which he wants to alienate, and, therefore, enables him to enter into any stipulation however restrictive it is, provided that restriction in the judgment of the Court is not unreasonable, having regard to the subject matter of the contract.”
Morris also summarized the general philosophy behind this area of the law:

The case in which the Court interferes for the purpose of protection is where use is made, not of the skill which the man may have acquired, but of the secrets of the trade or profession which he had no right to reveal to any one else—matters which depend to some extent on good faith.[4]

The emphasis on the reasonableness of a restrictive covenant is primarily due to the relative bargaining power of the parties.[5] The general assumption in Canadian law with respect to employees is that enforceable restrictions should be shorter and narrower for jobs that are less sophisticated or involve entry-level duties.
A number of cases have set out the test for determining when a post-employment restrictive covenant will be enforceable.[6]

Most covenants are drafted and imposed by the employer. As a result, the burden of establishing the reasonableness of the covenant is placed upon the employer.[7] Further, the legal maxim contra proferentum applies, and the courts will construe any ambiguity against the drafter of the covenant.
Every covenant must also be reasonable with respect to:[8]
the employer's legitimate business interests;
duration, geographical area and scope; and
the public interest.

With regard to item (a), the courts have held that a restrictive covenant is reasonable only if it is imposed to protect a legitimate interest.[9] Where a restrictive covenant is designed to eliminate competition, rather than protect a proprietary interest, it will not be enforced.[10] In Medtronic of Canada Ltd. v. Armstrong,[11] the court refused to enforce a restrictive covenant that would have effectively removed the employee from the industry in which he had spent his entire career.[12] Where information or techniques are well-known within an industry, non-competition clauses will likely be unenforceable.[13]
